Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Order! Order! Who’s the defendant today?
Looks pretty fancy. Indeed, Your Honor. This is Marie Antoinette,
the Queen of France who was notorious for living in opulence
while the peasants starved. That is sensationalist slander. Marie Antoinette had little power
over her circumstances and spent her brief life trying to survive
in a turbulent, foreign country. You mean she wasn't French? That’s right, Your Honor. She was born in 1755 as the
Hapsburg Archduchess Maria Antonia. After two of her older sisters
passed away, she became the only choice for a political
marriage to Louis-August, heir to the French throne. Essentially, she was sacrificed to secure
peace between Austria and France, all at the age of 14. She seemed to have had adjusted
to this “sacrifice” by 1774 when her husband was crowned king. She lived a life of luxury, 
wearing elaborate headdresses, importing foreign fabrics— she even had her own private chateau
near Versailles! Meanwhile, France was 
in an economic tailspin. Bad harvests resulted
in mass food shortages, wages were falling,
and the cost of living had skyrocketed. Marie Antoinette’s expensive tastes
were completely insensitive to the plight of her subjects. She was the Queen! If she hadn’t looked glamorous,
she would have been criticized. Besides, she sometimes used
her image for good. After convincing the King to be
vaccinated against smallpox, she commissioned a special headdress
to make the treatment fashionable for all. She also used her influence to appoint
unqualified friends and admirers to important posts. Even more disastrous, she encouraged
the King to get involved in the American Revolution, a conflict that cost France
1.5 billion francs. Objection! The Queen had very little influence over
her husband’s political decisions at that time. Besides, France’s financial crisis was
much more related to the country’s outdated tax system and lack
of an effective central bank. How so? While France's nobility and clergy
had numerous tax exemptions, peasants often paid more than half
their income in taxes. This system buried France in debt
long before the Queen's arrival. Her personal expenses were
merely a scapegoat for decades of financial negligence. That doesn’t change that Marie Antoinette
spent tax money on luxuries while the masses starved! She was so oblivious that when she heard
people couldn’t afford bread, she recommended they eat cake instead. This is almost certainly a fabrication
attributed to the Queen by her enemies. In fact, Marie Antoinette frequently
engaged in charity work focused on addressing poverty. Her reputation as a heartless queen
was based on rumors and slander. Even the most famous case against her
was a complete fraud. Pardon? In 1784, a thief forged fake letters
from the Queen to purchase an outrageously expensive
diamond necklace. The truth came out eventually, but the public already saw
her as a wasteful spendthrift. Meanwhile, it's really her husband
who ruined France's finances. On that, we agree. Louis XVI was an incompetent king. Even after the revolution began
and he lost much of his power to the newly formed National Assembly, he refused to yield control. Louis vetoed numerous pieces
of legislation— and he was supported 
by his conservative Queen. To a point. Marie Antoinette believed
in the divine right of kings, but despite personal reservations,
she tried to work with reformers. Though all she got in return were false
reports that she was sleeping with them. No amount of charity work could counter
this avalanche of slander. The revolutionaries also prevented
the King’s family from leaving Paris— how could she negotiate with people
keeping her prisoner? Well, they were right to do so! In 1791, the royal couple tried
fleeing to Austria to gather support and regain power. Even after they were caught, the King and Queen continued
to pass military secrets to their Austrian contacts. Isn't that treason? Certainly, and Louis was executed for it,
alongside 32 other charges. Even if you believe the King's
execution was just, there's no excuse for how the new
government treated Marie Antoinette. She was separated from her son
and kept in a cell with no privacy. The tribunal in charge of prosecuting 
the Queen had no proof of her treason, so they denigrated her with baseless
accusations of incest and orgies. Yet she maintained composure
until the very end. The Queen’s final words were an apology
to her executioner for stepping on his foot. However refined she may have been, Marie Antoinette was willing to betray
her country to stay in power. In life and death, she remains a symbol
of everything wrong with the decadent monarchy. A convenient symbol— and an example of the public’s appetite
for smearing prominent women with their own fantasies and frustrations. So what you’re saying is she
was guilty of being Queen? Should monarchs be judged 
by their personal qualities or the historical role they occupied? And can even the powerful be
victims of circumstance? These are the questions that arise
when we put history on trial.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The future Queen Marie Antoinette of France was born in
Options: A. Austria, B. France, C. England, D. Spain
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Marie Antoinette born? Options: A. France, B. Austria, C. Germany, D. Italy Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason for Marie Antoinette's marriage to Louis-August, heir to the French throne? Options: A. She fell in love with him, B. To secure peace between Austria and France, C. To become the Queen of France, D. To escape her family Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was one of the ways Marie Antoinette used her image for good? Options: A. She wore elaborate headdresses to show off her wealth, B. She convinced the King to be vaccinated against smallpox and made it fashionable, C. She appointed unqualified friends to important posts, D. She encouraged the King to get involved in the American Revolution Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was a significant factor contributing to France's financial crisis during Marie Antoinette's time? Options: A. The Queen's personal expenses, B. The country's outdated tax system and lack of an effective central bank, C. The American Revolution, D. The King's incompetence Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the likely origin of the phrase "Let them eat cake" attributed to Marie Antoinette? Options: A. A genuine quote from the Queen, B. A fabrication attributed to the Queen by her enemies, C. A phrase from a book written by the Queen, D. A phrase from a speech given by the Queen Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the French public perceive Marie Antoinette's reputation, and what was the basis for this perception? Options: A. They saw her as a heartless queen due to her charity work, B. They saw her as a wasteful spendthrift due to rumors and slander, C. They saw her as a kind queen due to her fashion sense, D. They saw her as a powerful queen due to her influence over the King Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the primary reason for the royal couple's attempted flight to Austria in 1791? Options: A. To escape the revolutionaries, B. To gather support and regain power, C. To attend a royal wedding, D. To go on vacation Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the outcome of the tribunal's prosecution of Marie Antoinette, and what tactics did they use? Options: A. She was found guilty of treason and executed, with the tribunal using baseless accusations of incest and orgies, B. She was found not guilty of treason and released, with the tribunal using fair and just methods, C. She was found guilty of treason and imprisoned, with the tribunal using fair and just methods, D. She was found not guilty of treason and executed, with the tribunal using baseless accusations of incest and orgies Correct Option: A
Question 9: What does the transcript suggest about the public's perception of prominent women, using Marie Antoinette as an example? Options: A. The public tends to admire and respect prominent women, B. The public tends to smear prominent women with their own fantasies and frustrations, C. The public tends to ignore prominent women, D. The public tends to fear prominent women Correct Option: B
Question 10: What question does the transcript raise about the judgment of monarchs, using Marie Antoinette as an example? Options: A. Should monarchs be judged solely by their personal qualities?, B. Should monarchs be judged solely by the historical role they occupied?, C. Should monarchs be judged by both their personal qualities and the historical role they occupied?, D. Should monarchs not be judged at all? Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Order! Order! Who’s the defendant today?
Looks pretty fancy. Indeed, Your Honor. This is Marie Antoinette,
the Queen of France who was notorious for living in opulence
while the peasants starved. That is sensationalist slander. Marie Antoinette had little power
over her circumstances and spent her brief life trying to survive
in a turbulent, foreign country. You mean she wasn't French? That’s right, Your Honor. She was born in 1755 as the
Hapsburg Archduchess Maria Antonia. After two of her older sisters
passed away, she became the only choice for a political
marriage to Louis-August, heir to the French throne. Essentially, she was sacrificed to secure
peace between Austria and France, all at the age of 14. She seemed to have had adjusted
to this “sacrifice” by 1774 when her husband was crowned king. She lived a life of luxury, 
wearing elaborate headdresses, importing foreign fabrics— she even had her own private chateau
near Versailles! Meanwhile, France was 
in an economic tailspin. Bad harvests resulted
in mass food shortages, wages were falling,
and the cost of living had skyrocketed. Marie Antoinette’s expensive tastes
were completely insensitive to the plight of her subjects. She was the Queen! If she hadn’t looked glamorous,
she would have been criticized. Besides, she sometimes used
her image for good. After convincing the King to be
vaccinated against smallpox, she commissioned a special headdress
to make the treatment fashionable for all. She also used her influence to appoint
unqualified friends and admirers to important posts. Even more disastrous, she encouraged
the King to get involved in the American Revolution, a conflict that cost France
1.5 billion francs. Objection! The Queen had very little influence over
her husband’s political decisions at that time. Besides, France’s financial crisis was
much more related to the country’s outdated tax system and lack
of an effective central bank. How so? While France's nobility and clergy
had numerous tax exemptions, peasants often paid more than half
their income in taxes. This system buried France in debt
long before the Queen's arrival. Her personal expenses were
merely a scapegoat for decades of financial negligence. That doesn’t change that Marie Antoinette
spent tax money on luxuries while the masses starved! She was so oblivious that when she heard
people couldn’t afford bread, she recommended they eat cake instead. This is almost certainly a fabrication
attributed to the Queen by her enemies. In fact, Marie Antoinette frequently
engaged in charity work focused on addressing poverty. Her reputation as a heartless queen
was based on rumors and slander. Even the most famous case against her
was a complete fraud. Pardon? In 1784, a thief forged fake letters
from the Queen to purchase an outrageously expensive
diamond necklace. The truth came out eventually, but the public already saw
her as a wasteful spendthrift. Meanwhile, it's really her husband
who ruined France's finances. On that, we agree. Louis XVI was an incompetent king. Even after the revolution began
and he lost much of his power to the newly formed National Assembly, he refused to yield control. Louis vetoed numerous pieces
of legislation— and he was supported 
by his conservative Queen. To a point. Marie Antoinette believed
in the divine right of kings, but despite personal reservations,
she tried to work with reformers. Though all she got in return were false
reports that she was sleeping with them. No amount of charity work could counter
this avalanche of slander. The revolutionaries also prevented
the King’s family from leaving Paris— how could she negotiate with people
keeping her prisoner? Well, they were right to do so! In 1791, the royal couple tried
fleeing to Austria to gather support and regain power. Even after they were caught, the King and Queen continued
to pass military secrets to their Austrian contacts. Isn't that treason? Certainly, and Louis was executed for it,
alongside 32 other charges. Even if you believe the King's
execution was just, there's no excuse for how the new
government treated Marie Antoinette. She was separated from her son
and kept in a cell with no privacy. The tribunal in charge of prosecuting 
the Queen had no proof of her treason, so they denigrated her with baseless
accusations of incest and orgies. Yet she maintained composure
until the very end. The Queen’s final words were an apology
to her executioner for stepping on his foot. However refined she may have been, Marie Antoinette was willing to betray
her country to stay in power. In life and death, she remains a symbol
of everything wrong with the decadent monarchy. A convenient symbol— and an example of the public’s appetite
for smearing prominent women with their own fantasies and frustrations. So what you’re saying is she
was guilty of being Queen? Should monarchs be judged 
by their personal qualities or the historical role they occupied? And can even the powerful be
victims of circumstance? These are the questions that arise
when we put history on trial.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: At her trial before the Revolutionary Tribunal in 1793, Marie Antoinette was charged with
Options: A. The Theft of the Crown Jewels, B. Colluding with her Austrian relatives to commit treason, C. Inciting a Rebellion in Provence, D. Increasing the price of bread
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Where was Marie Antoinette born? Options: A. France, B. Austria, C. Germany, D. Italy Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason for Marie Antoinette's marriage to Louis-August, heir to the French throne? Options: A. She fell in love with him, B. To secure peace between Austria and France, C. To become the Queen of France, D. To escape her family Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was one of the ways Marie Antoinette used her image for good? Options: A. She wore elaborate headdresses to show off her wealth, B. She convinced the King to be vaccinated against smallpox and made it fashionable, C. She appointed unqualified friends to important posts, D. She encouraged the King to get involved in the American Revolution Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was a significant factor contributing to France's financial crisis during Marie Antoinette's time? Options: A. The Queen's personal expenses, B. The country's outdated tax system and lack of an effective central bank, C. The American Revolution, D. The King's incompetence Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the likely origin of the phrase "Let them eat cake" attributed to Marie Antoinette? Options: A. A genuine quote from the Queen, B. A fabrication attributed to the Queen by her enemies, C. A phrase from a book written by the Queen, D. A phrase from a speech given by the Queen Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the French public perceive Marie Antoinette's reputation, and what was the basis for this perception? Options: A. They saw her as a heartless queen due to her charity work, B. They saw her as a wasteful spendthrift due to rumors and slander, C. They saw her as a kind queen due to her fashion sense, D. They saw her as a powerful queen due to her influence over the King Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the primary reason for the royal couple's attempted flight to Austria in 1791? Options: A. To escape the revolutionaries, B. To gather support and regain power, C. To attend a royal wedding, D. To go on vacation Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the outcome of the tribunal's prosecution of Marie Antoinette, and what tactics did they use? Options: A. She was found guilty of treason and executed, with the tribunal using baseless accusations of incest and orgies, B. She was found not guilty of treason and released, with the tribunal using fair and just methods, C. She was found guilty of treason and imprisoned, with the tribunal using fair and just methods, D. She was found not guilty of treason and executed, with the tribunal using baseless accusations of incest and orgies Correct Option: A
Question 9: What does the transcript suggest about the public's perception of prominent women, using Marie Antoinette as an example? Options: A. The public tends to admire and respect prominent women, B. The public tends to smear prominent women with their own fantasies and frustrations, C. The public tends to ignore prominent women, D. The public tends to fear prominent women Correct Option: B
Question 10: What question does the transcript raise about the judgment of monarchs, using Marie Antoinette as an example? Options: A. Should monarchs be judged solely by their personal qualities?, B. Should monarchs be judged solely by the historical role they occupied?, C. Should monarchs be judged by both their personal qualities and the historical role they occupied?, D. Should monarchs not be judged at all? Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 8: What was the outcome of the tribunal's prosecution of Marie Antoinette, and what tactics did they use?**

Although this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, it is the closest in terms of content and intent. The ground truth MCQ asks about the charges brought against Marie Antoinette at her trial, while Question 8 asks about the outcome of the tribunal's prosecution and the tactics used. However, both questions relate to the trial and the accusations made against Marie Antoinette.

The other generated MCQs do not match the ground truth MCQ as closely, as they focus on different aspects of Marie Antoinette's life and reign.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **8**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Concrete is the most widely used construction material in the world. It can be found in swathes of city pavements, bridges that span vast rivers, and the tallest skyscrapers on earth. But this sturdy substance does have a weakness: it’s prone to catastrophic cracking that costs tens of billions of dollars to repair each year. But what if we could avoid that problem, by creating concrete that heals itself? This idea isn’t as far-fetched as it may seem. It boils down to an understanding of how concrete forms, and how to exploit that process to our benefit. Concrete is a combination of coarse stone and sand particles, called aggregates, that mix with cement, a powdered blend of clay and limestone. When water gets added to this mix, the cement forms a paste and coats the aggregates, quickly hardening through a chemical reaction called hydration. Eventually, the resulting material grows strong enough to prop up buildings that climb hundreds of meters into the sky. While people have been using a variety of recipes to produce cement for over 4,000 years, concrete itself has a surprisingly short lifespan. After 20 to 30 years, natural processes like concrete shrinkage, excessive freezing and thawing, and heavy loads can trigger cracking. And it’s not just big breaks that count: tiny cracks can be just as dangerous. Concrete is often used as a secondary support around steel reinforcements. In this concrete, even small cracks can channel water, oxygen, and carbon dioxide that corrode the steel and lead to disastrous collapse. On structures like bridges and highways that are constantly in use, detecting these problems before they lead to catastrophe becomes a huge and costly challenge. But not doing so would also endanger thousands of lives. Fortunately, we’re already experimenting with ways this material could start fixing itself. And some of these solutions are inspired by concrete’s natural self-healing mechanism. When water enters these tiny cracks, it hydrates the concrete’s calcium oxide. The resulting calcium hydroxide reacts with carbon dioxide in the air, starting a process called autogenous healing, where microscopic calcium carbonate crystals form and gradually fill the gap. Unfortunately, these crystals can only do so much, healing cracks that are less than 0.3mm wide. Material scientists have figured out how to heal cracks up to twice that size by adding hidden glue into the concrete mix. If we put adhesive-filled fibers and tubes into the mixture, they’ll snap open when a crack forms, releasing their sticky contents and sealing the gap. But adhesive chemicals often behave very differently from concrete, and over time, these adhesives can lead to even worse cracks. So perhaps the best way to heal large cracks is to give concrete the tools to help itself. Scientists have discovered that some bacteria and fungi can produce minerals, including the calcium carbonate found in autogenous healing. Experimental blends of concrete include these bacterial or fungal spores alongside nutrients in their concrete mix, where they could lie dormant for hundreds of years. When cracks finally appear and water trickles into the concrete, the spores germinate, grow, and consume the nutrient soup that surrounds them, modifying their local environment to create the perfect conditions for calcium carbonate to grow. These crystals gradually fill the gaps, and after roughly three weeks, the hard-working microbes can completely repair cracks up to almost 1mm wide. When the cracks seal, the bacteria or fungi will make spores and go dormant once more— ready to start a new cycle of self-healing when cracks form again. Although this technique has been studied extensively, we still have a ways to go before incorporating it in the global production of concrete. But, these spores have huge potential to make concrete more resilient and long-lasting— which could drastically reduce the financial and environmental cost of concrete production. Eventually, these microorganisms may force us to reconsider the way we think about our cities, bringing our inanimate concrete jungles to life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the most widely used construction material in the world?
Options: A. Concrete, B. Bricks, C. Plastic materials, D. Composites
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the most widely used construction material in the world? Options: A. Steel, B. Concrete, C. Wood, D. Brick Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the process of how concrete forms. Options: A. A combination of coarse stone and sand particles mix with cement and water, then harden through a chemical reaction called hydration., B. A mixture of clay and limestone is added to water, then quickly hardens through a chemical reaction called hydration., C. Coarse stone and sand particles mix with cement, then harden through a process called autogenous healing., D. Cement forms a paste and coats aggregates, then quickly hardens through a process called concrete shrinkage. Correct Option: A
Question 3: A construction company is building a new bridge and wants to minimize the risk of cracking. What type of concrete mix would you recommend? Options: A. A mix with adhesive-filled fibers and tubes, B. A mix with bacterial or fungal spores alongside nutrients, C. A mix with a high concentration of cement, D. A mix with a low concentration of aggregates Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the natural self-healing mechanism of concrete? Options: A. Autogenous healing, B. Concrete shrinkage, C. Hydration, D. Calcium carbonate formation Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the maximum size of cracks that can be healed through autogenous healing? Options: A. 0.1mm, B. 0.3mm, C. 1mm, D. 2mm Correct Option: B
Question 6: Compare and contrast the use of adhesive-filled fibers and tubes versus bacterial or fungal spores in concrete self-healing. Options: A. Adhesive-filled fibers and tubes can heal larger cracks, while bacterial or fungal spores can only heal smaller cracks., B. Bacterial or fungal spores can heal larger cracks, while adhesive-filled fibers and tubes can lead to worse cracks over time., C. Adhesive-filled fibers and tubes are more expensive, while bacterial or fungal spores are more environmentally friendly., D. Bacterial or fungal spores are more difficult to implement, while adhesive-filled fibers and tubes are easier to use. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the role of bacteria and fungi in the self-healing process of concrete? Options: A. They produce minerals, including calcium carbonate, to fill gaps in the concrete., B. They break down the concrete mixture, allowing for new concrete to be poured., C. They strengthen the concrete by increasing its density., D. They reduce the environmental impact of concrete production. Correct Option: A
Question 8: Evaluate the potential benefits of using self-healing concrete in construction projects. Options: A. It could reduce the financial cost of concrete production, but increase the environmental impact., B. It could increase the financial cost of concrete production, but reduce the environmental impact., C. It could drastically reduce both the financial and environmental cost of concrete production., D. It could have no impact on either the financial or environmental cost of concrete production. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the current limitation of implementing self-healing concrete with bacterial or fungal spores? Options: A. It is too expensive to produce., B. It is too difficult to implement., C. It has not been studied extensively enough., D. It is not yet ready for global production. Correct Option: D
Question 10: How could the widespread adoption of self-healing concrete change the way we think about cities? Options: A. It could lead to the development of more sustainable cities., B. It could result in the creation of more densely populated cities., C. It could bring our inanimate concrete jungles to life., D. It could have no impact on urban planning. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: What is the most widely used construction material in the world? Options: A. Steel, B. Concrete, C. Wood, D. Brick Correct Option: B**

This question has the same intent and content as the ground truth MCQ, with the only difference being the options provided. The correct option, "Concrete", is the same in both questions.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **1**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

**Transcript**:
Concrete is the most widely used construction material in the world. It can be found in swathes of city pavements, bridges that span vast rivers, and the tallest skyscrapers on earth. But this sturdy substance does have a weakness: it’s prone to catastrophic cracking that costs tens of billions of dollars to repair each year. Question: In the presence of a calcium source, what is one of the most suitable fillers for concrete cracks due to its high compatibility with concrete compositions and its ability to be precipitated by some species of bacteria or fungi?
Options: A. Calcium oxalate, B. Calcium carbonate, C. Calcium chloride, D. Calcium sulfate
Correct Option: B

Question 9: What is the current limitation of implementing self-healing concrete with bacterial or fungal spores? Options: A. It is too expensive to produce., B. It is too difficult to implement., C. It has not been studied extensively enough., D. It is not yet ready for global production. Correct Option: D
Question 10: How could the widespread adoption of self-healing concrete change the way we think about cities? Options: A. It could lead to the development of more sustainable cities., B. It could result in the creation of more densely populated cities., C. It could bring our inanimate concrete jungles to life., D. It could have no impact on urban planning. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the role of bacteria and fungi in the self-healing process of concrete, which is related to the idea of a suitable filler for concrete cracks. The correct option in Question 7 mentions that bacteria and fungi produce minerals, including calcium carbonate, which is the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Concrete is the most widely used construction material in the world. It can be found in swathes of city pavements, bridges that span vast rivers, and the tallest skyscrapers on earth. But this sturdy substance does have a weakness: it’s prone to catastrophic cracking that costs tens of billions of dollars to repair each year. But what if we could avoid that problem, by creating concrete that heals itself? This idea isn’t as far-fetched as it may seem. It boils down to an understanding of how concrete forms, and how to exploit that process to our benefit. Concrete is a combination of coarse stone and sand particles, called aggregates, that mix with cement, a powdered blend of clay and limestone. When water gets added to this mix, the cement forms a paste and coats the aggregates, quickly hardening through a chemical reaction called hydration. Eventually, the resulting material grows strong enough to prop up buildings that climb hundreds of meters into the sky. While people have been using a variety of recipes to produce cement for over 4,000 years, concrete itself has a surprisingly short lifespan. After 20 to 30 years, natural processes like concrete shrinkage, excessive freezing and thawing, and heavy loads can trigger cracking. And it’s not just big breaks that count: tiny cracks can be just as dangerous. Concrete is often used as a secondary support around steel reinforcements. In this concrete, even small cracks can channel water, oxygen, and carbon dioxide that corrode the steel and lead to disastrous collapse. On structures like bridges and highways that are constantly in use, detecting these problems before they lead to catastrophe becomes a huge and costly challenge. But not doing so would also endanger thousands of lives. Fortunately, we’re already experimenting with ways this material could start fixing itself. And some of these solutions are inspired by concrete’s natural self-healing mechanism. When water enters these tiny cracks, it hydrates the concrete’s calcium oxide. The resulting calcium hydroxide reacts with carbon dioxide in the air, starting a process called autogenous healing, where microscopic calcium carbonate crystals form and gradually fill the gap. Unfortunately, these crystals can only do so much, healing cracks that are less than 0.3mm wide. Material scientists have figured out how to heal cracks up to twice that size by adding hidden glue into the concrete mix. If we put adhesive-filled fibers and tubes into the mixture, they’ll snap open when a crack forms, releasing their sticky contents and sealing the gap. But adhesive chemicals often behave very differently from concrete, and over time, these adhesives can lead to even worse cracks. So perhaps the best way to heal large cracks is to give concrete the tools to help itself. Scientists have discovered that some bacteria and fungi can produce minerals, including the calcium carbonate found in autogenous healing. Experimental blends of concrete include these bacterial or fungal spores alongside nutrients in their concrete mix, where they could lie dormant for hundreds of years. When cracks finally appear and water trickles into the concrete, the spores germinate, grow, and consume the nutrient soup that surrounds them, modifying their local environment to create the perfect conditions for calcium carbonate to grow. These crystals gradually fill the gaps, and after roughly three weeks, the hard-working microbes can completely repair cracks up to almost 1mm wide. When the cracks seal, the bacteria or fungi will make spores and go dormant once more— ready to start a new cycle of self-healing when cracks form again. Although this technique has been studied extensively, we still have a ways to go before incorporating it in the global production of concrete. But, these spores have huge potential to make concrete more resilient and long-lasting— which could drastically reduce the financial and environmental cost of concrete production. Eventually, these microorganisms may force us to reconsider the way we think about our cities, bringing our inanimate concrete jungles to life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Microbes can completely repair cracks up to what size?
Options: A. 0.3 mm, B. 0.5 mm, C. 1 mm, D. 10 mm
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the most widely used construction material in the world? Options: A. Steel, B. Concrete, C. Wood, D. Brick Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the process of how concrete forms. Options: A. A combination of coarse stone and sand particles mix with cement and water, then harden through a chemical reaction called hydration., B. A mixture of clay and limestone is added to water, then quickly hardens through a chemical reaction called hydration., C. Coarse stone and sand particles mix with cement, then harden through a process called autogenous healing., D. Cement forms a paste and coats aggregates, then quickly hardens through a process called concrete shrinkage. Correct Option: A
Question 3: A construction company is building a new bridge and wants to minimize the risk of cracking. What type of concrete mix would you recommend? Options: A. A mix with adhesive-filled fibers and tubes, B. A mix with bacterial or fungal spores alongside nutrients, C. A mix with a high concentration of cement, D. A mix with a low concentration of aggregates Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the natural self-healing mechanism of concrete? Options: A. Autogenous healing, B. Concrete shrinkage, C. Hydration, D. Calcium carbonate formation Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the maximum size of cracks that can be healed through autogenous healing? Options: A. 0.1mm, B. 0.3mm, C. 1mm, D. 2mm Correct Option: B
Question 6: Compare and contrast the use of adhesive-filled fibers and tubes versus bacterial or fungal spores in concrete self-healing. Options: A. Adhesive-filled fibers and tubes can heal larger cracks, while bacterial or fungal spores can only heal smaller cracks., B. Bacterial or fungal spores can heal larger cracks, while adhesive-filled fibers and tubes can lead to worse cracks over time., C. Adhesive-filled fibers and tubes are more expensive, while bacterial or fungal spores are more environmentally friendly., D. Bacterial or fungal spores are more difficult to implement, while adhesive-filled fibers and tubes are easier to use. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the role of bacteria and fungi in the self-healing process of concrete? Options: A. They produce minerals, including calcium carbonate, to fill gaps in the concrete., B. They break down the concrete mixture, allowing for new concrete to be poured., C. They strengthen the concrete by increasing its density., D. They reduce the environmental impact of concrete production. Correct Option: A
Question 8: Evaluate the potential benefits of using self-healing concrete in construction projects. Options: A. It could reduce the financial cost of concrete production, but increase the environmental impact., B. It could increase the financial cost of concrete production, but reduce the environmental impact., C. It could drastically reduce both the financial and environmental cost of concrete production., D. It could have no impact on either the financial or environmental cost of concrete production. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the current limitation of implementing self-healing concrete with bacterial or fungal spores? Options: A. It is too expensive to produce., B. It is too difficult to implement., C. It has not been studied extensively enough., D. It is not yet ready for global production. Correct Option: D
Question 10: How could the widespread adoption of self-healing concrete change the way we think about cities? Options: A. It could lead to the development of more sustainable cities., B. It could result in the creation of more densely populated cities., C. It could bring our inanimate concrete jungles to life., D. It could have no impact on urban planning. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What is the maximum size of cracks that can be healed through autogenous healing? Options: A. 0.1mm, B. 0.3mm, C. 1mm, D. 2mm Correct Option: B

However, the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ is 1 mm, which is related to the self-healing process using microbes, not autogenous healing. Therefore, a more similar question would be one that specifically asks about the self-healing process using microbes.

A more similar generated MCQ would be Question 3's option B description or Question 6's option B description, but they are not exact matches.

If I had to choose one, I would say Question 5 is the closest match, but with some differences in the question's content.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

**Transcript**:
Concrete is the most widely used construction material in the world. It can be found in swathes of city pavements, bridges that span vast rivers, and the tallest skyscrapers on earth. But this sturdy substance does have a weakness: it’s prone to catastrophic cracking that costs tens of billions of dollars to repair each year. But what if we could avoid that problem, by creating concrete that heals itself? This idea isn’t as far-fetched as it may seem. It boils down to an understanding of how concrete forms, and how to exploit that process to our benefit. Concrete is a combination of coarse stone and sand particles, called aggregates, that mix with cement, a powdered blend of clay and limestone. When water gets added to this mix, the cement forms a paste and coats the aggregates, quickly hardening through a chemical reaction called hydration. Eventually, the resulting material grows strong enough to prop up buildings that climb hundreds of meters into the sky. While people have been using a variety of recipes to produce cement for over 4,000 years, concrete itself has a surprisingly short lifespan. After 20 to 30 years, natural processes like concrete shrinkage, excessive freezing and thawing, and heavy loads can trigger cracking. And it’s not just big breaks that count: tiny cracks can be just as dangerous. Concrete is often used as a secondary support around steel reinforcements. In this concrete, even small cracks can channel water, oxygen, and carbon dioxide that corrode the steel and lead to disastrous collapse. On structures like bridges and highways that are constantly in use, detecting these problems before they lead to catastrophe becomes a huge and costly challenge. But not doing so would also endanger thousands of lives. Fortunately, we’re already experimenting with ways this material could start fixing itself. And some of these solutions are inspired by concrete’s natural self-healing mechanism. When water enters these tiny cracks, it hydrates the concrete’s calcium oxide. The resulting calcium hydroxide reacts with carbon dioxide in the air, starting a process called autogenous healing, where microscopic calcium carbonate crystals form and gradually fill the gap. If we put adhesive-filled fibers and tubes into the mixture, they’ll snap open when a crack forms, releasing their sticky contents and sealing the gap. But adhesive chemicals often behave very differently from concrete, and over time, these adhesives can lead to even worse cracks. So perhaps the best way to heal large cracks is to give concrete the tools to help itself. Scientists have discovered that some bacteria and fungi can produce minerals, including the calcium carbonate found in autogenous healing. Experimental blends of concrete include these bacterial or fungal spores alongside nutrients in their concrete mix, where they could lie dormant for hundreds of years. When cracks finally appear and water trickles into the concrete, the spores germinate, grow, and consume the nutrient soup that surrounds them, modifying their local environment to create the perfect conditions for calcium carbonate to grow. These crystals gradually fill the gaps, and after roughly three weeks, the hard-working microbes can completely repair cracks up to almost 1mm wide. Although this technique has been studied extensively, we still have a ways to go before incorporating it in the global production of concrete. But, these spores have huge potential to make concrete more resilient and long-lasting— which could drastically reduce the financial and environmental cost of concrete production. Eventually, these microorganisms may force us to reconsider the way we think about our cities, bringing our inanimate concrete jungles to life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Microbes can completely repair cracks after roughly how long?
Options: A. Three days, B. Three weeks, C. Three years, D. Three months
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the grasslands of Mauritania, a gazelle suffering from tuberculosis 
takes its last breath. Collapsing near a small pool, the animal’s corpse 
threatens to infect the water. But for the desert’s cleanup crew, 
this body isn’t a problem: it’s a feast. Weighing up to 10 kilograms and possessing a wingspan 
of nearly 3 meters, the lappet-faced vulture 
is the undisputed king of the carcass. This bird’s powerful beak and strong neck easily tear through tough hide 
and muscle tissue, opening entry points 
for weaker vultures to dig in. This colossal competition is too dangerous
for the tiny Egyptian vulture. With a wingspan of only 180 centimeters, this vulture migrated to Africa 
from his family nest in Portugal, using thermal updrafts to stay aloft 
for hours at a time. But upon arrival, he finds himself near 
the bottom of the pecking order. Fortunately, what he lacks in size, 
he makes up for in intelligence. A short distance away, 
he spots an unguarded ostrich nest, full of immense, but impenetrable eggs. Using a large rock, he smashes one open
for a well-earned meal— though he’ll circle back to the gazelle 
once the larger birds are gone. High above the commotion 
are Ruppell’s Griffon vultures. Soaring at an altitude 
of over 11,000 meters, these birds fly higher 
than any other animal. At this height, they can’t see 
individual carcasses. But the sight of their fellow vultures 
guides them to the feeding. Their featherless heads help them regulate the sudden rise in temperature 
as they descend— and keep them clean 
as they tear into the decaying gazelle. The carcass is stripped clean in hours, well before the rotting meat 
infects the water supply. And the tuberculosis doesn’t 
stand a chance at infecting the vultures. These birds have evolved the lowest 
gastric pH in the animal kingdom, allowing them to digest diseased 
carrion and waste without becoming sick. In fact, species like 
the mountain-dwelling bearded vulture have stomachs so acidic, they can digest most bones 
in just 24 hours. This adaptation helps smaller vultures 
supplement their diet with dung, while larger vultures can consume 
diseased meat up to 3 days old. Their acidic stomachs protect them 
from living animals too: their rancid vomit 
scares off most predators. These stomachs of steel are essential 
to removing pathogens like cholera, anthrax, and rabies 
from the African ecosystem. But while vultures can easily digest 
natural waste, man-made chemicals are another story. Diclofenac, a common veterinary drug 
used to treat cattle in India, is fatal to vultures. And because local religious beliefs 
prohibit eating beef, scavengers often consume cattle carcasses. Since the 1990s, the drug, along with threats from electricity pylons
and habitat loss, has contributed to a 95% decline 
in the region’s vulture population. In nearby Africa, 
poachers intentionally poison carcasses to prevent the birds’ presence from 
alerting authorities to their location. One poisoned carcass can kill 
over 500 vultures. Today, more than 50% of all vulture 
species are endangered. In regions where vultures 
have gone extinct, corpses take three times longer to decay. These carcasses contaminate 
drinking water, while feral dogs and rats carry 
the diseases into human communities. The Asian and African Vulture Crisis 
has led to an epidemic of rabies in India, where infections kill roughly 
20,000 people each year. Fortunately, some communities have already
realized how important vultures are. Conservationists have successfully banned
drugs like Diclofenac, while other researchers are working 
to repopulate vulture communities through breeding programs. Some regions have even opened 
vulture restaurants where farmers safely dispose 
of drug-free livestock. With help, vultures will be able 
to continue their role conserving the health of our planet—
transforming death and decay into life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Egyptian vultures evolved the ability to use tools. What do they use to crack open ostrich eggs?
Options: A. Sticks, B. Fire, C. Rocks, D. Branches
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the typical wingspan of a lappet-faced vulture? Options: A. 1 meter, B. 2 meters, C. Nearly 3 meters, D. 4 meters Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why is the Egyptian vulture unable to compete with larger vultures for food from the gazelle carcass? Options: A. It is too slow, B. It is too small, C. It is too weak, D. It is too tired Correct Option: B
Question 3: What adaptation allows vultures to digest diseased carrion without becoming sick? Options: A. Strong beaks, B. Featherless heads, C. Low gastric pH, D. Strong necks Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the result of a decline in vulture populations in a region? Options: A. Carcasses decay faster, B. Carcasses take longer to decay, C. The ecosystem becomes healthier, D. The water supply becomes cleaner Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why do poachers intentionally poison carcasses in Africa? Options: A. To kill vultures for their feathers, B. To prevent vultures from alerting authorities to their location, C. To protect their livestock, D. To hunt vultures for sport Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the estimated number of people killed by rabies infections in India each year? Options: A. 1,000, B. 5,000, C. 10,000, D. 20,000 Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the name of the veterinary drug that is fatal to vultures and has contributed to a decline in their population? Options: A. Diclofenac, B. Anthrax, C. Cholera, D. Rabies Correct Option: A
Question 8: How do Ruppell's Griffon vultures locate carcasses from high altitudes? Options: A. By sight, B. By smell, C. By following other vultures, D. By using thermal updrafts Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the purpose of vulture restaurants in some regions? Options: A. To feed vultures, B. To breed vultures, C. To safely dispose of drug-free livestock, D. To hunt vultures Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the overall role of vultures in conserving the health of the planet? Options: A. To spread diseases, B. To contaminate water supplies, C. To transform death and decay into life, D. To compete with other scavengers Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly listed. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, we can identify a generated MCQ that shares some similarities.

The ground truth MCQ asks about Egyptian vultures using tools to crack open ostrich eggs. While there isn't a direct match among the generated MCQs, Question 2 mentions the Egyptian vulture's inability to compete with larger vultures for food from the gazelle carcass due to its small size. This question is related to the Egyptian vulture but does not specifically address the use of tools.

However, if we were to choose a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ, it would be Question 2. Nevertheless, it is essential to note that the generated MCQs do not directly address the use of tools by Egyptian vultures.

If I had to choose an index, I would say Question 2 is the closest match, but it is not a direct match.

Index: 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the grasslands of Mauritania, a gazelle suffering from tuberculosis 
takes its last breath. Collapsing near a small pool, the animal’s corpse 
threatens to infect the water. But for the desert’s cleanup crew, 
this body isn’t a problem: it’s a feast. Weighing up to 10 kilograms and possessing a wingspan 
of nearly 3 meters, the lappet-faced vulture 
is the undisputed king of the carcass. This bird’s powerful beak and strong neck easily tear through tough hide 
and muscle tissue, opening entry points 
for weaker vultures to dig in. This colossal competition is too dangerous
for the tiny Egyptian vulture. With a wingspan of only 180 centimeters, this vulture migrated to Africa 
from his family nest in Portugal, using thermal updrafts to stay aloft

has led to an epidemic of rabies in India, where infections kill roughly

to repopulate vulture communities through breeding programs. Some regions have even opened 
vulture restaurants where farmers safely dispose 
of drug-free livestock. With help, vultures will be able 
to continue their role conserving the health of our planet—
transforming death and decay into life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What adaptation have vultures evolved that allows them to digest diseased carrion and waste without becoming sick?
Options: A. Sharpest teeth in the animal kingdom, B. Lowest gastric pH in the animal kingdom, C. Strongest muscles in the animal kingdom, D. Ability to soar the highest altitude in the animal kingdom
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the typical wingspan of a lappet-faced vulture? Options: A. 1 meter, B. 2 meters, C. Nearly 3 meters, D. 4 meters Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why is the Egyptian vulture unable to compete with larger vultures for food from the gazelle carcass? Options: A. It is too slow, B. It is too small, C. It is too weak, D. It is too tired Correct Option: B
Question 3: What adaptation allows vultures to digest diseased carrion without becoming sick? Options: A. Strong beaks, B. Featherless heads, C. Low gastric pH, D. Strong necks Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the result of a decline in vulture populations in a region? Options: A. Carcasses decay faster, B. Carcasses take longer to decay, C. The ecosystem becomes healthier, D. The water supply becomes cleaner Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why do poachers intentionally poison carcasses in Africa? Options: A. To kill vultures for their feathers, B. To prevent vultures from alerting authorities to their location, C. To protect their livestock, D. To hunt vultures for sport Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the estimated number of people killed by rabies infections in India each year? Options: A. 1,000, B. 5,000, C. 10,000, D. 20,000 Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the name of the veterinary drug that is fatal to vultures and has contributed to a decline in their population? Options: A. Diclofenac, B. Anthrax, C. Cholera, D. Rabies Correct Option: A
Question 8: How do Ruppell's Griffon vultures locate carcasses from high altitudes? Options: A. By sight, B. By smell, C. By following other vultures, D. By using thermal updrafts Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the purpose of vulture restaurants in some regions? Options: A. To feed vultures, B. To breed vultures, C. To safely dispose of drug-free livestock, D. To hunt vultures Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the overall role of vultures in conserving the health of the planet? Options: A. To spread diseases, B. To contaminate water supplies, C. To transform death and decay into life, D. To compete with other scavengers Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the adaptation that allows vultures to digest diseased carrion and waste without becoming sick. The correct option in both questions is related to the low gastric pH of vultures. Although the wording of the options is slightly different, the overall content and intent of the questions are the same.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the grasslands of Mauritania, a gazelle suffering from tuberculosis 
takes its last breath. Collapsing near a small pool, the animal’s corpse 
threatens to infect the water. But for the desert’s cleanup crew, 
this body isn’t a problem: it’s a feast. Weighing up to 10 kilograms and possessing a wingspan 
of nearly 3 meters, the lappet-faced vulture 
is the undisputed king of the carcass. This bird’s powerful beak and strong neck easily tear through tough hide 
and muscle tissue, opening entry points 
for weaker vultures to dig in. This colossal competition is too dangerous
for the tiny Egyptian vulture. With a wingspan of only 180 centimeters, this vulture migrated to Africa 
from his family nest in Portugal, using thermal updrafts to stay aloft 
for hours at a time. But upon arrival, he finds himself near 
the bottom of the pecking order. Fortunately, what he lacks in size, 
he makes up for in intelligence. A short distance away, 
he spots an unguarded ostrich nest, full of immense, but impenetrable eggs. Using a large rock, he smashes one open
for a well-earned meal— though he’ll circle back to the gazelle 
once the larger birds are gone. High above the commotion 
are Ruppell’s Griffon vultures. Soaring at an altitude 
of over 11,000 meters, these birds fly higher 
than any other animal. At this height, they can’t see 
individual carcasses. But the sight of their fellow vultures 
guides them to the feeding. Their featherless heads help them regulate the sudden rise in temperature 
as they descend— and keep them clean 
as they tear into the decaying gazelle. The carcass is stripped clean in hours, well before the rotting meat 
infects the water supply. And the tuberculosis doesn’t 
stand a chance at infecting the vultures. These birds have evolved the lowest 
gastric pH in the animal kingdom, allowing them to digest diseased 
carrion and waste without becoming sick. In fact, species like 
the mountain-dwelling bearded vulture have stomachs so acidic, they can digest most bones 
in just 24 hours. This adaptation helps smaller vultures 
supplement their diet with dung, while larger vultures can consume 
diseased meat up to 3 days old. Their acidic stomachs protect them 
from living animals too: their rancid vomit 
scares off most predators. These stomachs of steel are essential 
to removing pathogens like cholera, anthrax, and rabies 
from the African ecosystem. But while vultures can easily digest 
natural waste, man-made chemicals are another story. Diclofenac, a common veterinary drug 
used to treat cattle in India, is fatal to vultures. And because local religious beliefs 
prohibit eating beef, scavengers often consume cattle carcasses. Since the 1990s, the drug, along with threats from electricity pylons
and habitat loss, has contributed to a 95% decline 
in the region’s vulture population. In nearby Africa, 
poachers intentionally poison carcasses to prevent the birds’ presence from 
alerting authorities to their location. One poisoned carcass can kill 
over 500 vultures. Today, more than 50% of all vulture 
species are endangered. In regions where vultures 
have gone extinct, corpses take three times longer to decay. These carcasses contaminate 
drinking water, while feral dogs and rats carry 
the diseases into human communities. The Asian and African Vulture Crisis 
has led to an epidemic of rabies in India, where infections kill roughly 
20,000 people each year. Fortunately, some communities have already
realized how important vultures are. Conservationists have successfully banned
drugs like Diclofenac, while other researchers are working 
to repopulate vulture communities through breeding programs. Some regions have even opened 
vulture restaurants where farmers safely dispose 
of drug-free livestock. With help, vultures will be able 
to continue their role conserving the health of our planet—
transforming death and decay into life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following has NOT contributed to the 95% decline in the India’s vulture population?
Options: A. Diclofenac, a common veterinary drug, B. Threats from electricity pylons, C. Habitat loss, D. Vulture restaurants
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the typical wingspan of a lappet-faced vulture? Options: A. 1 meter, B. 2 meters, C. Nearly 3 meters, D. 4 meters Correct Option: C
Question 2: Why is the Egyptian vulture unable to compete with larger vultures for food from the gazelle carcass? Options: A. It is too slow, B. It is too small, C. It is too weak, D. It is too tired Correct Option: B
Question 3: What adaptation allows vultures to digest diseased carrion without becoming sick? Options: A. Strong beaks, B. Featherless heads, C. Low gastric pH, D. Strong necks Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the result of a decline in vulture populations in a region? Options: A. Carcasses decay faster, B. Carcasses take longer to decay, C. The ecosystem becomes healthier, D. The water supply becomes cleaner Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why do poachers intentionally poison carcasses in Africa? Options: A. To kill vultures for their feathers, B. To prevent vultures from alerting authorities to their location, C. To protect their livestock, D. To hunt vultures for sport Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the estimated number of people killed by rabies infections in India each year? Options: A. 1,000, B. 5,000, C. 10,000, D. 20,000 Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the name of the veterinary drug that is fatal to vultures and has contributed to a decline in their population? Options: A. Diclofenac, B. Anthrax, C. Cholera, D. Rabies Correct Option: A
Question 8: How do Ruppell's Griffon vultures locate carcasses from high altitudes? Options: A. By sight, B. By smell, C. By following other vultures, D. By using thermal updrafts Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the purpose of vulture restaurants in some regions? Options: A. To feed vultures, B. To breed vultures, C. To safely dispose of drug-free livestock, D. To hunt vultures Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the overall role of vultures in conserving the health of the planet? Options: A. To spread diseases, B. To contaminate water supplies, C. To transform death and decay into life, D. To compete with other scavengers Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. However, it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it only asks about one of the factors that contributed to the decline in India's vulture population (Diclofenac), whereas the ground truth MCQ asks which of the following has NOT contributed to the decline.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that asks about the factors contributing to the decline in vulture population and includes "vulture restaurants" as an option. Unfortunately, such a question is not present among the generated MCQs.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and intent, I would choose Question 9, as it mentions "vulture restaurants" and their purpose, which is related to the conservation of vultures and indirectly to the decline in their population.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 9

In the grasslands of Mauritania, a gazelle suffering from tuberculosis 
takes its last breath. Collapsing near a small pool, the animal’s corpse 
threatens to infect the water. But for the desert’s cleanup crew, 
this body isn’t a problem: it’s a feast. Weighing up to 10 kilograms and possessing a wingspan 
of nearly 3 meters, the lappet-faced vulture 
is the undisputed king of the carcass. This bird’s powerful beak and strong neck easily tear through tough hide 
and muscle tissue, opening entry points 
for weaker vultures to dig in. This colossal competition is too dangerous
for the tiny Egyptian vulture. With a wingspan of only 180 centimeters, this vulture migrated to Africa 
from his family nest in Portugal, using thermal updrafts to stay aloft 
for hours at a time. But upon arrival, he finds himself near 
the bottom of the pecking order. Fortunately, what he lacks in size, 
he makes up for in intelligence. A short distance away, 
he spots an unguarded ostrich nest, full of immense, but impenetrable eggs. Using a large rock, he smashes one open
for a well-earned meal— though he’ll circle back to the gazelle 
once the larger birds are gone. High above the commotion 
are Ruppell’s Griffon vultures. Soaring at an altitude 
of over 11,000 meters, these birds fly higher 
than any other animal. At this height, they can’t see 
individual carcasses. But the sight of their fellow vultures 
guides them to the feeding. Their featherless heads help them regulate the sudden rise in temperature 
as they descend— and keep them clean 
as they tear into the decaying gazelle. The carcass is stripped clean in hours, well before the rotting meat 
infects the water supply. And the tuberculosis doesn’t 
stand a chance at infecting the vultures. These birds have evolved the lowest 
gastric pH in the animal kingdom, allowing them to digest diseased 
carrion and waste without becoming sick. In fact, species like 
the mountain-dwelling bearded vulture have stomachs so acidic, they can digest most bones 
in just 24 hours. This adaptation helps smaller vultures 
supplement their diet with dung, while larger vultures can consume 
diseased meat up to 3 days old. Their acidic stomachs protect them 
from living animals too: their rancid vomit 
scares off most predators. These stomachs of steel are essential 
to removing pathogens like cholera, anthrax, and rabies 
from the African ecosystem. But while vultures can easily digest 
natural waste, man-made chemicals are another story. Diclofenac, a common veterinary drug 
used to treat cattle in India, is fatal to vultures. And because local religious beliefs 
prohibit eating beef, scavengers often consume cattle carcasses. Since the 1990s, the drug, along with threats from electricity pylons
and habitat loss, has contributed to a 95% decline 
in the region’s vulture population. In nearby Africa, 
poachers intentionally poison carcasses to prevent the birds’ presence from 
alerting authorities to their location. One poisoned carcass can kill 
over 500 vultures. Today, more than 50% of all vulture 
species are endangered. In regions where vultures 
have gone extinct, corpses take three times longer to decay. These carcasses contaminate 
drinking water, while feral dogs and rats carry 
the diseases into human communities. The Asian and African Vulture Crisis 
has led to an epidemic of rabies in India, where infections kill roughly 
20,000 people each year. Fortunately, some communities have already
realized how important vultures are. Conservationists have successfully banned
drugs like Diclofenac, while other researchers are working 
to repopulate vulture communities through breeding programs. Some regions have even opened 
vulture restaurants where farmers safely dispose 
of drug-free livestock. With help, vultures will be able 
to continue their role conserving the health of our planet—
transforming death and decay into life.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Vultures are real life superheroes. How can we protect them, so in return they help us?
Options: A. Ban drugs like Diclofenac, B. Support researchers who are working on vulture breeding programs, C. Participate at a vulture restaurant, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

is the undisputed king of the carcass. This bird’s powerful beak and strong neck easily tear through tough hide 
and muscle tissue, opening entry points 
for weaker vultures to dig in. This colossal competition is too dangerous
for the tiny Egyptian vulture. With a wingspan of only 180 centimeters, this vulture migrated to Africa 
from his family nest in Portugal, using thermal updrafts to stay aloft 
for hours at a time. But upon arrival, he finds himself near

for a well-earned meal— though he’ll circle back to the gazelle 
once the larger birds are gone. High above the commotion 
are Ruppell’s Griffon vultures. Soaring at an altitude 
of over 11,000 meters, these birds fly higher 
than any other animal. At this height, they can’t see 
individual carcasses. But the sight of their fellow vultures 
guides them to the feeding. Their featherless heads help them regulate the sudden rise in temperature 
as they descend— and keep them clean 
as they tear into the decaying gazelle. The carcass is stripped clean in hours, well before the rotting meat 
infects the water supply. And the tuberculosis doesn’t 
stand a chance at infecting the vultures. These birds have evolved the lowest 
gastric pH in the animal kingdom, allowing them to digest diseased 
carrion and waste without becoming sick. In fact, species like 
the mountain-dwelling bearded vulture have stomachs so acidic, they can digest most bones 
in just 24 hours. This adaptation helps smaller vultures 
supplement their diet with dung, while larger vultures can consume

to removing pathogens like cholera, anthrax, and rabies 
from the African ecosystem. But while vultures can easily digest

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Lord Sun dawns on the day called 7-Monkey, his fingers slowly spreading a rosy sheen that mixes softly with smoke rising 
from Tenochtitlan’s many hearth fires. The midwife, Xoquauhtli, 
has a difficult choice to make. A momentous shift from rainy season 
to dry season is underway. All summer, the gods have kept 
the people fed with corn, but the fertile summer months 
are disappearing. This day occurs during the festival 
that marks the shift between the summer season,
when the gods feed the people, and the winter season,
when the people feed the gods in return. Xoquauhtli owes a debt 
to her patron, Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess 
at the center of this festival. Teteoinnan wages war both 
on women’s battlefields of birth and in men’s battles 
with Tenochtilan’s enemies. She must be kept happy 
or she will bring bad luck. The midwife should participate 
in the festival today, but one of her patients could 
go into labor any minute. Xoquauhtli decides to check 
on her patient first. The expecting mother hasn’t 
worked too hard, chewed gum, or lifted heavy things. Her family is taking good care of her. Surely Xoquauhtli can take a little time 
to honor her goddess. She leaves her apprentice in charge 
and heads to the center of the city. Along the way, she sees women sweeping
the roads and hanging gourds in preparation for the festival. Finally, she reaches the Great Pyramid. On top are two temples: the north, where rituals honor 
the rain god in the summer, and the south one is where rituals 
honor the war god in the winter. On the equinox, the sun rises 
between the two sides. The ceremony begins with a mock battle 
between the midwives and the other physicians. Xoquauhtli’s team battles heartily, 
throwing nochtles, marigolds, and balls made of reed and moss. They joke, call their rivals names, 
and laugh. But then, a girl comes running 
with a message for Xoquauhtli. Her patient is in labor! She hurries back to the house. All the old women 
from the extended family have already gathered for the birth— their experience is very valuable 
if anything goes wrong. She readies herself with a prayer praising
her most important tools, her fingers. Then she doses the patient with cihuapatli
to help expel the baby, massages her in the sweathouse, 
and rubs her stomach with tobacco. Offering Teteoinnan a short prayer, she urges her patient 
to act like a warrior. A strong baby girl slips 
into her waiting hands and the old women shout triumphant cries. Xoquauhtli takes a few drops of water 
from a jade bowl, breaths on them, and places them on the baby’s tiny tongue. She calls her a precious greenstone, 
a little warrior, and tells her how the Lord and Lady 
of the Ninth Sky breathed life into her, sending her 
to this place of burden and torment. She then turns to the new mother, 
praising her, telling her she acted like 
an eagle warrior, a jaguar warrior. By the time they finish, it’s late, 
and the flames of the fire have died down. Xoquauhtli piles the remaining hot coals 
in the center of the hearth, stoking them to keep them going. She lays the baby in a woven basket, 
head facing the warming fire. This will warm her tonalli, 
an important “soul” center in the body central to health and well-being. It’s almost midnight— 
if Xoquauhtli hurries, she can get back to the temple 
for the culmination of the festival. She makes her way to the city center, 
where a priest carries a woman on his back to the top of the pyramid. To begin the new season and feed the gods,
she will be beheaded, symbolizing how corn is cut in the fields. Afterward, she will be reborn 
as Lady Teteoinnan, and preside over the induction 
of new warriors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who is the midwife in this story and what did she do?
Options: A. Tenochtli, an experienced woman warrior who, when not attending to birthing mothers, battled opponents on the field of war., B. Xoquauhtli, an older woman, who attended both a sacrificial ritual and the birth of a baby girl., C. Luchadora, a young woman who kept herself fit for the rigors of childbirth by battling other wrestlers., D. Totoltin, an elderly lady who provided valued assistance during the birth, thereby saving the baby from death.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the midwife Xoquauhtli's difficult choice on the day of the festival? Options: A. Whether to attend the festival or stay home with her family, B. Whether to participate in the festival or check on her patient who was about to give birth, C. Whether to honor her patron goddess or ignore her obligations, D. Whether to attend the mock battle between midwives and physicians or skip it Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the significance of the festival that Xoquauhtli attended? Options: A. It marked the beginning of the summer season, B. It marked the shift from rainy season to dry season, C. It marked the end of the winter season, D. It marked the harvest season Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the role of Teteoinnan, the female warrior goddess, in the festival? Options: A. She was the patron goddess of the midwives, B. She was the goddess of fertility and childbirth, C. She was the goddess of war and the protector of the city, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 4: What was the purpose of the mock battle between the midwives and physicians during the festival? Options: A. To demonstrate their medical skills, B. To showcase their physical strength, C. To symbolize the battle between life and death, D. To add a lighthearted and humorous element to the festival Correct Option: D
Question 5: What was the name of the plant used by Xoquauhtli to help expel the baby during childbirth? Options: A. Cihuapatli, B. Nochtles, C. Marigold, D. Tobacco Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the significance of the jade bowl and water in the birth ritual? Options: A. It was used to purify the baby, B. It was used to bless the baby, C. It was used to welcome the baby to the world, D. It was used to give the baby her first drink of water Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the purpose of placing the baby in a woven basket with her head facing the warming fire? Options: A. To keep her warm and cozy, B. To symbolize her connection to the natural world, C. To warm her tonalli, an important "soul" center in the body, D. To protect her from evil spirits Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the significance of the woman being beheaded at the culmination of the festival? Options: A. It symbolized the sacrifice of the gods, B. It symbolized the cycle of life and death, C. It symbolized the cutting of corn in the fields, D. It symbolized the power of the priests Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the role of the priest in the culmination of the festival? Options: A. He performed the sacrifice of the woman, B. He carried the woman on his back to the top of the pyramid, C. He presided over the induction of new warriors, D. He led the prayers and rituals Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the outcome of the woman's sacrifice at the culmination of the festival? Options: A. She was reborn as a goddess, B. She was reborn as a warrior, C. She was reborn as Lady Teteoinnan and presided over the induction of new warriors, D. She was not reborn and was simply a sacrifice Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.
